case_vignette: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother because of a large head contusion and altered mental status. At first, the mother says her son got injured when a “pot fell from a shelf onto his head.” Later, she changes the story and says that he hit his head after “tripping over a football.” Physical examination shows cracks in the suture lines of the skull, and there is a flattened appearance to the bone. The patient’s father arrives to inquire on how his son is “recovering from his fall down the stairs.” Upon request to interview the patient alone, the parents refuse, complaining loudly about the request.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a big bump on my head and I'm not acting like myself.
Can you tell me your age and sex?
I'm a 3-year-old boy.
Have you had any head injuries or accidents recently?
Yes, something fell on my head.
Have you been taking any medications for any other conditions?
No, I haven't been taking any medications for other conditions.
Do you have any family history of head injuries or neurological conditions?
I don't know about any family history of head injuries or neurological conditions.
Final Diagnosis: Subdural Hematoma.

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A 3-year-old boy presents with a big bump on his head and is not acting like himself. He reports that something fell on his head. There is no history of taking any medications for other conditions, and he is unaware of any family history of head injuries or neurological conditions.
trial_0.vignette_frq: The most likely diagnosis in this patient is a non-accidental head injury (NAHI), also known as shaken baby syndrome.
